turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Hochelaga (village).
turn.2: He declared that the mountain would be named Mount Royal, in honour of King Francis I of France, as was customary in that period.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: Cartier then visited Hochelaga, and notes its organization: "The said town is all in a circle, enclosed in wood, in three ranks, in the manner of a pyramid, crossed at the top, having a row perpendicular to it all.
turn.5: Is there anything else noteable about this article?
turn.6: And this town there is only one door and entrance.
turn.7: What happened after Cartier visited Hochelaga?
turn.8: There are within this town roughly fifty houses, each about fifty steps long, and…"  He then gives a detailed description of the interior of a longhouse and how people lived in it: "…in each one of them, there are several hearths and several rooms. " In the center of each house was a common room, where the indigenous people built a fire and lived as a community.
turn.10: When the tour of the village was over, Cartier and his companions were then guided up Mount Royal, probably on the back of a man, according to a custom of courtesy he mentions further down.
turn.11: What did they do when they reached the top of Mount Royal?
turn.12: The mountain was "distant from the village by about a quarter-league".
